results.title: The Man in the glass booth
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hiller, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and Cinevision Ltee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Searing adaptation made for the American Film Theatre collection, of the Robert Shaw play, about a wealthy Jewish man living in Manhattan who is beset by demons and paranoia. A survivor of the Holocaust, Arthur Goldman is one day kidnapped and shipped to Israel where he is tried for war crimes. But is this character the victim or the perpetrator? With its claustrophobic and minimalist setting, Arthur Hiller teases out the themes of guilt, paranoia, conspiracy theories and martyrdom. Maximillian Schell was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Goldman, but the adaptation itself was controversial, with Shaw removing his name from the credits, due to dissatisfaction with Edward Anhalt’s screenplay.

results.title: Introduction film for the American Enterprise series
results.creator_credit: James C. Crimmins, Mike Jackson and Playback Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Documentary on five 30 minute Films of American Enterprise from early pioneer days to the present day, emphasis on teamwork and organisational skills. Narrated by William Shatner.

results.title: Government
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Describes through the eyes of a middle-management Social Security employee, the role America’s government - the largest single employer, spender, borrower, and consumer in the country - has played in determining America’s economic growth. It tells why, and where the government has been involved in communications, agriculture, forestry, mining, transportation, banking and commerce, workers’ rights, health and welfare, and protection of the environment. Presented by William Shatner.

results.title: Innovation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Features John Tench, an industrial scientist who views himself as an incarnation of the traditional American inventor. Features the history of innovation in US technology; electronics, manufacturing, transportation, communications, engineering and business. The role of the US Patent Office is explained.

results.title: Land
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
A series of views on America’s economic history. This film presents an intriguing and entertaining account of how the earth helped shape the destiny of the United States - how the rich, fertile earth goaded people into prosperity. Features William Shatner.

results.title: People
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Tom Novak, community college professor of Ethnic Studies, visits Ellis Island, where he reminisces about the early immigrants (16 million between 1890 and 1930) who helped shape America. Novak introduces us to some of their descendants in their homes and businesses. Japanese florists in California, Portuguese fishermen in Massachusetts and an Afro-American family in Long Island are featured. Narrated by William Shatner.

group_works.creator_credit: James C. Crimmins, Mike Jackson and Playback Associates

results.title: Organization
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Lew Kraft, a successful and dynamic businessman, who is building a large shopping centre, opens up the intriguing and complex world of high finance and organisational know-how. The film then traces American economics from 18th century examples of community and farm organisation, through the complexity of the industrial and transportation revolutions, to modern-day international investments and multinational corporations and the organisational knack of Americans. With William Shatner.

results.title: Romantic comedy
results.creator_credit: Molly Ornati, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “American cinema”.
Breezy and silly to witty and intelligent, romantic comedies have been around since the 1930’s but the surface humour barely masked issues of gender and sexuality. This program reviews screwball comedies including “It happened one night” and “His girl Friday” and analyses more recent interpretations of the genre by directors like Nora Ephron and James Brooks.

results.title: The Studio system
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American cinema”.
This program surveys Hollywood’s industrial past during the era of contract players and directors, studio police forces and colourful movie moguls. It also overviews the modern film-making environment with studio heads Michael Eisner, Howard Koch and others. Paramount Pictures, one of the oldest and most successful of the Hollywood studios, serves as a case study.
